Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Automatic Control of Landfill Gas Collection
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project seeks to improve the commercial viability of technology that enables the real time measurement and control of landfill gas extraction systems. It has the potential to improve the economics of the Landfill Gas to Energy (LFG-E) market and reduce the environmental impact of landfills. With industry-wide implementation, annual revenues from existing LFG-E projects could be increased by over $450 million. The additional energy produced would power over 350,000 homes. Methane is a powerful greenhouse gas (GHG), and the EPA estimates that in 2011, emissions from landfills accounted for nearly 17.5% of generation from all manmade sources in the US. The associated reduction in GHG emissions from improved landfill gas collection would be equivalent to the emissions of over 3.6 billion gallons of gasoline or 76 million barrels of oil. Furthermore, because of the improved economics, this Phase II project could encourage the development of new LFG-E projects, further expanding the size and value of this market. According to EPA estimates, currently undeveloped sites could account for an additional 850 MW of power generation, enough to power over 508,000 homes.

The technical objectives of the project are 1) to reduce the cost of various system components, and 2) to address new product requirements related to third party safety and other certifications that are demanded by the market. The approach to cost reduction is to replace several commercially available off-the-shelf components (specifically, NDIR gas sensors and an electrically-actuated control valve) with custom designed alternatives that can meet product functional requirements at a 30% reduction in cost. In order to achieve the certifications that are demanded by the market it will be necessary to define the specific standards and protection concepts that are applicable, and then re-engineer hardware in accordance with these standards. This will involve a combination of component substitution and system re-design, depending on the specific protection concept(s) and hazardous location classification that are identified. The research will build upon the reliability and product functionality improvements that were a key outcome of the Phase I project, and successful completion of the research goals will enable more widespread adoption of real time control technology in the landfill gas industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the three years that Loci Controls has worked on the SBIR NSF Phase II project, Loci has made significant progress commercializing the results from our research and development efforts.   Loci has developed and commercialized automated landfill gas collection services to landfills that both increase methane capture and reduce harmful greenhouse gases (GHG) and other air pollutants from landfills using capital equipment designed by Loci with SBIR NSF support.  The landfill gas collection at most landfills in the US is regulated by the Clean Air Act and is subject to US EPA and State regulatory oversight.  Since landfill gas is a regulated air pollutant, adoption of Loci technology?which fundamentally change the gas collection process?has needed to overcome industry concerns about increased regulatory or compliance risk. To help overcome this initial resistance, Loci chose to build and own the specialty control equipment we have designed, and we provide this equipment and support to the landfill gas collection system operators as a service which is payable monthly.

In 2018, Loci generated just under $1M of revenue from Loci automated landfill gas collection services.  In 2019 revenue more than doubled to $2.1M, and revenue is expected to nearly double again in 2020 to over $3.6M despite significant market challenges due to the Covid-19 pandemic.  This represents 70% growth in service revenue vs. 2019.  Based on the size of the market which Loci can address and continued expected growth and market adoption of Loci automated landfill gas collection service, revenue is expected to grow by greater than 50% compounded annual growth rate for the next five years or longer.  2021 should result in Loci?s first year of EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) operations, a very significant milestone in our development.

Loci has been able to raise $22,069,271 of Series B Preferred Stock equity investment June 2017, which leveraged the results of the SBIR NSF Phase I and Phase II grants Loci had received to support the development of automated landfill gas collection equipment.  This investment was led by Houston and Dallas Texas private equity firm, Turnbridge Capital Partners, but included participation from earlier investors Massachusetts Clean Energy Center, Converge partners, as well as several individual private angel investors.  This investment has allowed Loci to invest in the capital equipment necessary to expand our automated landfill gas collection services, as well as fund sales and marketing efforts, and operating losses to support Loci commercial growth plans.

According to the US EPA, methane emissions from landfills are one of the largest sources of domestic GHG emissions.  A 2018 EPA estimate stated that methane emissions from landfills resulted in over 100 million metric tons of CO2 equivalent (CO2e) GHG emissions.  This is the amount of emissions equivalent to 20 million cars per year. Landfills were estimated to be the third largest man-made source of methane emissions, behind only the oil and gas industry and entire domestic livestock and agriculture industry.

The EPA estimates that average gas collection efficiency at landfills is approximately 75%.  Loci has quantified that use of its automated landfill gas collection system has the potential to reduce emissions from landfills by 50% or more.  Based on measured increases in gas collection, it is estimated that the use of Loci has reduced emissions since 2017 by over 1 million metric tons of CO2e.  In 2020 alone, Loci automated gas collection control technology reduced emissions by approximately 500,000 metric tons/year, an amount equal to the emissions of over 100,000 passenger vehicles in the US. Over the next 3 - 5 years, if Loci is deployed on the 1,000 largest landfills in the US, Loci can reduce GHG emissions by 50 million metric tons/year.  This is an amount of emissions equal to the annual emissions of more than 10 Million passenger cars.

Between 2009 and 2019, $365B has been invested to increase wind and solar electricity generation in the US.  (source: US Energy Information Administration).  The annual GHG emission reduction impact from the past 10 years of investment in wind and solar electricity in the United States, has resulted in a reduction of 200 million metric tons/year of GHG emission reduction. (source: US EPA).  In comparison, over the next 3 - 5 years, Loci can reduce GHG emission by an amount equal to 25% of the benefit of the past 10 years of solar/wind investment in the US, for $150M?which is less than 0.5%?of the last 10 years? worth of investment in wind & solar, and would require no additional land use or infrastructure investment.

Due to the support of the NSF SBIR Phase I and Phase II research projects, Loci is growing rapidly, has leveraged over $20M of additional private investment to support our future growth and will have a remarkable impact to reduce GHG emissions.
